content.p: Now let's summarize some key ideas.
Based on what you've seen on the applet (with the level set at 95%), decide which of the following statements are true and which are false.

question.body: 1. Each interval is centered at the population mean (μ).

response.name: true
response.feedback: Incorrect. The population mean (μ) won't necessarily be at the exact center of the confidence intervals. Remember, on the applet, the population mean was represented by the green line, and it wasn't always at the exact center of the intervals.

response.name: false
response.feedback: Correct. The population mean (μ) won't necessarily be at the exact center of the confidence intervals. On the applet, the population mean was represented by the green line, and it wasn't always at the exact center of the intervals.

question.body: 2. Each interval is centered at the sample mean (x-bar).

response.name: true
response.feedback: Correct. As you saw on the applet, each interval was centered at a dot that represented a sample mean (x-bar). In fact, a confidence interval is always made with the sample mean (x-bar) at the center.

response.name: false
response.feedback: Incorrect. Remember, on the applet, each interval was centered at a dot that represented a sample mean (x-bar). In fact, a confidence interval is always made with the sample mean (x-bar) at the center.

question.body: 3. The population mean (μ) changes when different samples are selected.

response.name: true
response.feedback: Incorrect. The population mean (μ) is a parameter, so it doesn't change. Remember, on the applet, the population mean was indicated by the green line, which didn't change position along the axis.

response.name: false
response.feedback: Correct. The population mean (μ) is a parameter, so it doesn't change. On the applet, the population mean was indicated by the green line, which didn't change position along the axis.

question.body: 4. The sample mean (x-bar) changes when different samples are selected.

response.name: true
response.feedback: Correct. The sample mean (x-bar) is a statistic that changes from sample to sample. On the applet, each sample mean (x-bar) was represented by a dot in the middle of each interval, and each dot was in a different position along the axis.

response.name: false
response.feedback: Incorrect. The sample mean (x-bar) is a statistic that changes from sample to sample. Remember, on the applet, each sample mean (x-bar) was represented by a dot in the middle of each interval, and each dot was in a different position along the axis.

question.body: 5. In the long run, only 95% of the intervals will contain (or "cover") the sample mean (x-bar).

response.name: true
response.feedback: Incorrect. Each confidence interval is centered at the sample mean (x-bar); remember, on the applet, each sample mean (x-bar) was represented by a dot in the middle of each interval. So all the intervals will contain their sample mean, not just 95% of the intervals.

response.name: false
response.feedback: Correct. In fact, 100% of the intervals will contain their sample mean, not only 95% of the intervals, because each confidence interval is centered at the sample mean (x-bar); each x-bar was represented on the applet by the dot in the middle of each interval.

question.body: 6. In the long run, only 95% of the intervals will contain (or "cover") the population mean (μ).

response.name: true
response.feedback: Correct. With the confidence level set at 95%, you saw that in the long run (if you selected many thousands of samples) 95% of the intervals would cover the green line, which represented the population mean (μ).

response.name: false
response.feedback: Incorrect. Remember you saw that in the long run (if you selected many thousands of samples) 95% of the intervals would cover the green line, which represented the population mean (μ). This is the meaning of the 95%.
